battles.description: This map is set in the tropical waters of the Caribbean.
Gentle hills and distant fields lie around this fort.
The fort dominates this slightly rugged map.
Many small rivers make negotiating this map a difficult tactical task.
Claustrophobic battlefield set between the walls of a canyon.
Seize the ridges to achieve dominance over your opponent.
Teammates are split apart at opposite ends of the map, and must battle separately for survival.
Gently rolling landscape with several villages to occupy.
Use the outer hills to capture the all-important centre.
Tactical manoeuvring will benefit players here as they seek to capture the high ground.
Completely flat map designed for balanced tournament play.
Bleak landscape designed to test generals' skills to their utmost.
Battle rages among the various villages and houses on this rural landscape.
Pitched battle amidst the maze-like rock formations of the Austrian Alps, encouraging tactical cunning and intelligent flanking.
The lack of river crossings here encourages strategic play.
This map features a hill and some substantial copses to reward crafty commanders.
Divide your army effectively to prevent your opponent becoming too strong in any one place.
Teams begin at the bottom of the hill, and must take risks and fight to out-manoeuvre each other to take the summit.
A large hill is in the centre of this battlefield, and control of it will no doubt be the source of much conflict.
A river divides deployment zones and armies, encouraging tactical play.
A flat map with a few forests and loggers' cabins to provide tactical interest.
With armies deploying in flooded swamps, commanders will need to mobilise quickly to take firmer ground.
A ridge dominates this desert map, giving a great advantage to those who capture it first.
A series of ridges intertwine in the centre of the battlefield, enabling interesting strategies.
Positioning and flanking is crucial here, as the high rock formations limit mobility.
Large cliffs overlook the deployment zones, forcing rapid mobilisation.

The Battle of Waterloo (18 June, 1815) proved to be Napoleon's last action. The combined British, Hanoverian, Prussian and Dutch-Belgian force of the Seventh Coalition decisively defeated Napoleon and his loyal generals, ending the emperor's rule forever and leading to his exile on the Atlantic island of St. Helena.

The Battle of Arcole (15-17 November, 1796) during which Napoleon successfully outflanked the Austrian army and carried the Tricolour across the Alpone river in person. By seizing the bridge the French prevented the escape of the Austrians, and therefore their planned relief of the siege at Mantua.
The Battle of Austerlitz (2 December, 1805) in which Napoleon masterminded his greatest ever victory by defeating the combined armies of Austria and Russia on the vast Pratzen Heights.

The Battle of Borodino (7 September, 1812) saw Napoleon force a close defeat upon the determined Russian defenders. Borodino would be the bloodiest battle of the Russian campaign for both sides, paving the way for Napoleon's subsequent march on Moscow.

The Battle of Dresden (26-27 August, 1813) during which Napoleon reversed the predicted outcome by arriving with reinforcements to bolster the city's defences. The Sixth Coalition were taken by surprise, resulting in the infliction of a heavy defeat upon them.
The Battle of Friedland (14 June, 1807) with Napoleon's empire at its height, he took a chance and defeated Russia in detail, knocking them out of the war and bringing the Fourth Coalition to an end.

The Battle of Ligny (16th June, 1815) effectively determined the outcome of Napoleon's 100 day return to power. Although victory was achieved here Blucher was allowed to escape, something which very soon proved to be a fatal mistake.

The Battle of Lodi (10 May, 1796) although not a decisive meeting, this was where Napoleon first made a name for himself and got a glimpse of his destiny. The nickname "the little corporal" remained with him throughout his early campaigns against Austria.

The Battle of the Nile or Aboukir Bay (August 1-2, 1798) enabled the British Navy to take the upper hand in the Mediterranean, destroying the French fleet and stranding Napoleon and his army in Egypt.
The Battle of the Pyramids (21 July, 1798) where Napoleon deployed his lethal divisional squares in the shadow of the Great Pyramids at Giza, defeating a fearless Mameluke cavalry force.

The Battle of Trafalgar (21 October 1805) forever confirmed Britain's naval supremacy, leaving the Franco-Spanish fleet, Villeneuve's career and Napoleon's invasion plans in tatters off the coast of Spain.

The Battle of Waterloo (18 June, 1815) proved to be Napoleon's last action. The combined British, Hanoverian, Prussian and Dutch-Belgian force of the Seventh Coalition decisively defeated Napoleon and his loyal generals, ending the emperor's rule forever and leading to his exile on the Atlantic island of St. Helena.

The combined British, Hanoverian, Prussian and Dutch-Belgian force of the Seventh Coalition decisively defeated Napoleon and his loyal generals, ending the emperor's rule forever and leading to his exile on the Atlantic island of St. Helena.

The Battle of Waterloo (18 June, 1815) proved to be Napoleon's last action. The combined British, Hanoverian, Prussian and Dutch-Belgian force of the Seventh Coalition decisively defeated Napoleon and his loyal generals, ending the emperor's rule forever and leading to his exile on the Atlantic island of St. Helena.

The Battle of Waterloo (18 June, 1815) proved to be Napoleon's last action. The combined British, Hanoverian, Prussian and Dutch-Belgian force of the Seventh Coalition decisively defeated Napoleon and his loyal generals, ending the emperor's rule forever and leading to his exile on the Atlantic island of St. Helena.

The Battle of Waterloo (18 June, 1815) proved to be Napoleon's last action. The combined British, Hanoverian, Prussian and Dutch-Belgian force of the Seventh Coalition decisively defeated Napoleon and his loyal generals, ending the emperor's rule forever and leading to his exile on the Atlantic island of St. Helena.
Located along the Alpone river, the town of Arcole with its strategic bridge nestles in sprawling Italian farmland with treacherous marshes running along its river banks.

Dominated by the vast surrounding hills, the Goldbach Stream flows through the villages of Kobelnitz, Sokolnitz, and Telnitz. With the focal point of the battlefield being the Pratzen Heights, a vast, gently sloping hill.

Deep within the borders of Russia the Bagration's flches are a series of disconnected earthworks which run in an arc from the Moskva River and its tributaries all the way to the imposing Raevsky redoubt near the town of Borodino.
Situated within the Dresden Elbe Valley and along the river Elbe, stands the poorly fortified town of Dresden and its Royal gardens.
Southeast of Knigsberg, the bends of the Alle river meander past the Sortlack Woods and the villages of Posthenen and Friedland.
Surrounded by fields, the small village of Ligny is located on the watershed between the Scheldt and Meuse rivers. The windmills of Brye and Naveau offer a suitable vantage point of the battlefield.
Established around the river Po, the town of Lodi with its stone bridge and local fords sits perfectly in the rolling hills of the Italian countryside.
Close to Alexandria on Egypt's Mediterranean coast, the Bay of Aboukir has many treacherous shoals and reefs beneath its waters.
Almost in the shadow of the Great Pyramids of Giza, the ever-changing Egyptian desert encroaches on the fertile banks of the Nile.
The waters off of the southern coast of Spain near Cadiz, offer the perfect setting for a naval encounter.
Sat in idyllic Belgian countryside south of Brussels, the hilly Ohain road passes through Waterloo and its numerous farms, hamlets and nearby villages.
Rolling hills and sparse trees surround this fort.
Gentle hills surround a huge fort.
This fort outside the city of El Arish lies amidst a harsh desert landscape, affording little cover for assaulting forces.
The fort lies in the confluence of Haine and Escaut rivers, making approaching the fort difficult, demanding strong army positioning on the part of the attackers.
This fort was originally built by the United Provinces to protect against Spanish attack. A nearby river and coast makes it well-protected.
This coastal fort is surrounded by woodlands and atop a hill, providing excellent defensibility.
The fort lies at the mouth of the river Gironde, providing an exceptionally strong position overlooking the shipping lanes. Cover is sparse, giving the defenders excellent sightlines.
This fort lies along the French coast, at the closest point to England. The fort sits atop the cliffs, providing a commanding defensive position.
This fort has an enviable position on the coast, surrounded by cliffs on three sides. The attacker will need to employ devious tactics to achieve victory.
The fort overlooks the town, which provides cover for approaching forces, but the nearby rivers make deployment critical.
This inland fort lies amidst thick forest and rolling hills. Attackers would do well to use the forest to their advantage, employing stealthy tactics using the cover of the trees.
This map has the massive fort set amongst a mix of open and hilly terrain.
This flat map is dominated by the central fort.
The fort sits on a central hill which dominates this map.

The Battle of Waterloo (18 June, 1815) Napoleon had the feeling he had won the war as he advanced towards the Anglo-Dutch army at Waterloo. The Prussians were retreating, pursued by a French corps, and only Wellington remained. French arms would be victorious once again, and the Empire would be reborn in fire. But the history book on the shelf would not be repeating itself
Fierce battle over a small town on the outskirts of the Salamanca province of Spain.
Two mighty flooded riverbeds feed the verdant farmland here, creating a relatively flat but highly tactical battlefield.
Skirmish amid the majestic peaks of the Pyrenees.
